history.content:
Financial Aid does ask for 6 units of Summer classes, so make sure you take that into account (otherwise it's thousands of dollars out of pocket)


In my opinion, I think taking CS 188 over the summer is a bit better than a regular semester looking at which is more generous at grading.
Data 100 does cover a lot of data processing and table techniques that I think are ultra-important in Machine Learning because data can be very unclean or you can gain the intuition on how to use table functions to pre-process the data using methods you will learn in CS 189 and 182 (like Normalization for one)
The only downside of Data 100 is that the homeworks and doesn't have public autograders, and uses very simple sanity tests, so you do need to double and triple check your work, which may be a pain in the butt unless you can converge to an answer with partners

If you can spend one week before exams to grind practice exams and you can do the Counting and Probability of CS 70 + Algorithms of CS 61B, then you can do CS 188 fine (you do lose out on the opportunity to take Data 100 without Data 8 tho, but maybe do Data 8 P/NP over the Summer, maybe, especially for the 6 unit Financial Aid thing)
As you noted, it's only the exams that are difficult, but mitigable with practice exams as you get used to their convoluted English

Financial Aid does ask for 6 units of Summer classes, so make sure you take that into account (otherwise it's thousands of dollars out of pocket)

In my opinion, I think taking Data 100 over the summer is a bit better, as it gives a high-level overview of the topics of Machine Learning and reinforced the topics of counting and probability in an easier way than CS 70 that is important in the first third of CS 188.

Data 100 does cover a lot of data processing and table techniques that I think are ultra-important in Machine Learning because data can be very unclean or you can gain the intuition on how to use table functions to pre-process the data using methods you will learn in CS 189 and 182 (like Normalization for one)

The only downside of Data 100 is that the homeworks and doesn't have public autograders, and uses very simple sanity tests, so you do need to double and triple check your work, which may be a pain in the butt unless you can converge to an answer with partners

If you can spend one week before exams to grind practice exams and you can do the Counting and Probability of CS 70 + Algorithms of CS 61B, then you can do CS 188 fine (you do lose out on the opportunity to take Data 100 without Data 8 tho, but maybe do Data 8 P/NP over the Summer, maybe, especially for the 6 unit Financial Aid thing)

As you noted, it's only the exams that are difficult, but mitigable with practice exams as you get used to their convoluted English

children.subject: CS 188 summer has nicer exams, at least last summer, i would recommend that over data100.

history.content:
Hello, 

I’m currently deciding between taking data 100 or CS 188 this summer. Does anyone have any insights or opinions on which one I should take?

In terms of my interests, I think AI is slightly more interesting because I would like to get into robotics / embedded systems. I know data 100 is an incredibly useful class industry class as well. 

Data 100 Pro & Cons:
+ Last opportunity to take it without data 8
+ good industry skills
- a little less relevant to my interests but still good to know

CS 188 Pros & Cons:
+ I’ve heard that the class has some really cool projects
+ aligns slightly better with my interests
- difficult exams but that’s not a dealbreaker. Berkeley is difficult in general loool

In terms of my summer commitments, I do 20-30 hr / week research. Thanks for your inputs!
history.subject: Summer Data 100 vs CS 188
